The experts are hit and miss because this is a CORPORATE recession; we're in uncharted waters as much of our economy is NOW made up of huge multinationals. The constant yammering of the news media "...but in todays economy!..." doesn't help. If it's appropriate sure, but we're hearing that phase in unrelated (to the economy) stories. Mega bonuses are at a preposterous rate right now and I don't see how that possibly could help the overall economy. It's almost to the point where when a company makes 100 million they give 50 million to the boss.
But completely off the charts as far as the MSM is concerned? Young people aged say 16 to 30. The idea of working for one company and making your way "up the ladder"? Laughable for people of that age group, and for good reason, "up the ladder" is actually a rare occurance nowadays. The idea of having only one job? Again quite foreign to the age group, they work two, three, even several, some related to their fields of study, or career, some not; all basically part time. Dedication? Maybe if they work in a real small place; but again the younger ones seem very aware that the large companies and huge multinationals will throw them to the wind if need be; why go above and beyond, it no longer leads to raises or promotions. My friend's son works in a nightclub. He has a degree and wants to work in his field; but starting salaries are barely what he gets hourly at the nightclub. He told me, "the hourly isn't bad, I get tips (pocketed) and some nights it's kinda fun." A far cry from the boomers, who cheered a moonwalk, created the computer industry, vastly expanded media, entertainment, and sports, kept pace with a rapidlly climbing housing market, and started families of their own. The younger generation I speak of doesn't seem to see career as a definition of personality as it's been in the past. Do you blame them?

My parents have had an egg for a decade. They got my wife and I one as a graduation gift in 2007. It's incredible. Everything is delicious. I'm a North Carolinian in California, and it barbecues pork butts brilliantly. If you know how North Carolinians feel about their pulled pork, that's worth the money right there.

Temperature control is easy and stable for hours (though we do have to check on it a couple times for overnight smoking, as it can go out). It's easy and fast to light (though it can take up to 20 min to get up to temperature), and the wind is never a problem.

My wife is Colombian, so steak is constantly on the menu, and it's always flavorful. Every chicken breast is moist. Roast vegetables get a smoky flavor. We bake bread, cookies, pizzas. The temperature gets up to 650 F easily, and 750 F if we push it.

And I think that it's popular--I have a blog of recipes that I maintain for my family, and the only post that gets hits from strangers--many thousands of hits, steadily--is a simple list of the times and temperatures for grilling on eggs.

An interesting piece of information.  ON this same date, July 16, but of 1950, Uruguay pulled what is considered the biggest upset in the history of soccer.  In Maracana stadium, in front of a 200,000 crowd, it defeated the host, Brazil, in the final of the World Cup.  Given the system used at the time, Brazil would have won the cup with a tie.  And Brazil ended the first half up 1-0.  But Uruguay scored twice in the 2nd half.  64 Brazilian men are said to have had heart attacks that day.  The improbable feat is remembered as the "Maracanzo".  It is intriguing and fitting that Uruguay achieved another feat, perhaps even harder, on the same date, 61 years later.  Let's call it the "Argentinazo".

WHH@42: I think "context of intent" is what is meant, and I confess the whole thing leaves me flat. (Otherwise one could say we have semantic nihilism.)

Martin@48: Thank you for your response. My quibble is actually with the word "unscientific".

In doing geophysical research there is little control over the data one can measure, and much too often hypotheses need to be framed or tested (and textbooks written) on the basis of extremely sparse data, verging on scientific impropriety in the eyes of some. So, where does one really draw the boundary between "scientific" and "unscientific" in connection with the sparseness of the data?

My attitude is that gathering such data -- no matter how sparse its collective state is at any given time -- is an ongoing process. One hopes sufficient "spot tests" -- so to speak -- can be obtained to indicate how hypotheses should be supported or altered. This by no means suggests that a spot test or other limited observation is "unscientific". (Anyone who sees a connect with recent news about difficulties in research for treatment for cancer would not be far off the mark.)

In a real case in point about earthquake activity, a colleague told me that for a year or two after the huge San Francisco earthquake in 1906, the incidence of earthquake activity in that region was found significantly "below normal" -- as if earthquakes there took a "quiet holiday". He said that this same type of "quiet period" is now being observed in the region around the recent gigantic earthquake off the coast of Japan that caused the devastating tsunami. I would be hard put to call these data and their inferences "unscientific".

As a means of collecting data (a.k.a. "getting results"), spot tests are a legitimate and well-sanctioned method. But as the sole means to a final conclusion, absolutely not.

Dear Thomas,

That was brilliant argument, both in terms of long term strategical meaning of this debt; as well as what it really will mean domestically. However, I think you over-looked some "unspoken assumption" that seemed to be playing in the background.

And, that is, there is a sense, that, from here on out (at least for most of the industrialized western democratic countries) will be dealing with a diminish economical pie (both internally and between themselves).

Hence, the political sense is that no matter what we in the west do now, our days of being the top "economical dogs" are really behind us and furthermore since no one has yet articulated how we are going to beat this new coming power (namely china) on the economical competition front; then, that assumption is taking to be "truth" of our future.

Consequently, people begin to think it may not be a bad idea to hold on to what they got so far and let everyone else sink or swim which really getting to be the prevailing reality of most western countries.

And, that notion, as you will understand will make people fearful of the future, as well as making them fractious in-terms of looking each other suspiciously. And therefore, politics itself becomes (at least at the national level), at best, as that of managing ever-splintering factional in-fighting, like what Mr. Obama is trying to do with his budget negotiation.

Or at worst it will become a scene of sectional grandstanding, like the manner that horrible man by the name Mr. E. Cantor is trying to do with America's credit worthiness.

All in all; I really fear for the western political scene for the coming few years. Unless we miraculously run into a large GDP growth of 5% to 6% on a sustain basis for at least a decade like 1990s.

If, however, that later scenario is too fanciful then I fear we must "borrow" a chapter from Britain's post-war history particularly what they used to called it "managing decline" as best we could under the circumstances.

It’s quite a stretch to cast a whole generation born in the boom years as the culprits in a national fiscal scandal which we are selfishly willing to our progeny. This is buying into the David Brooks School of Thought, which deflects blame onto generational conceits rather than where it really belongs: the corrupt global cabal of bankers, corporations and the bought and paid for politicians everywhere.

But if you insist on playing the Boomer blame game, let’s look at two powerful individuals from that era of selfish hedonism. First, President Bill Clinton: born into the working class, a self-made man who left the country with a surplus when he left the presidency. And then there was George Bush II, he of the proverbial silver spoon and foot in mouth, destroying every business venture he ever touched and almost single-handedly grinding this nation into a bottomless crater through tax cuts for millionaires and unpaid-for wars for the sole and exclusive benefit of the profiteers.

Eric Cantor was born so late in the Baby Boomer Era (1963),I think it’s safe to label him only with the first word of that appellation. His self-selected high school yearbook quote was “I want what I what when I want it.” He is the very model of a modern major pain.

As for your Greco-American meme of nations gone bad, that’s another false equivalence. The GOP spinners use Greece as a cautionary tale of what will happen here if we don’t get our own fiscal house in order. While the Greek government was inept and improvident in handling its own economy, a lot of the onus should be on the global banking system, which gladly loaned Greece a ton of money it can’t repay. The only similarity between us and them is that the “hoi polloi” are the only ones hurting. The banks aren't being forced to take the haircut, neither here nor there.

Many of us who are Republicans (and some of us who are Democrats) are greedy and power hungry. We believe that we are the entitled ones.
It is by the luck of the draw and by the problems in our economic model that some of us are unreasonably wealthy; not because we are genetically superior to others.
The fact is that our Tree of Liberty is being poisoned to its roots by the love of money for money's sake, the love of power and control over others for the sake of demeaning others, and the love of self for the sake of feeling superior to others.
We need to:
-Genuinely love our neighbors and our selves.
-Increase taxes on unreasonably wealthy corporations and individuals.
-Use some of the resulting revenue to pay off the debt and develop economic opportunities in America.
-Use some of the resulting revenue so that poverty will be eliminated and every one of us can have sufficient incomes and live healthy lives here in America.
-Provide education for everyone so that the wealthiest and the least wealthy among us can learn how to responsibly manage our incomes, including disposable income.
-Responsibly grow the national economy and responsibly incur debt.

Those of us who are wealthy will still be very wealthy, just not unreasonably wealthy.

Our consciences will be clearer. We will behave more constructively with one another. Very few of us, Americans, will act in ways to cause another American's life to be worthless.
Our greed is unhealthy our children and other living things.

The enemy is us.
Stand Up With President Obama!
Do not let yourselves be bullied by the bullies among us. Do not bully others.

The most obvious problem with collective action is one of intention. The whole goal has only been to stabilize the economy and begin to drive growth again. But how exactly is growth defined? What kind of growth? What does it mean to have a strong economy?

We keep looking at the money as if shifting it around or printing more of it will somehow solve our problems. But money isn't the problem. It's what we want to do with it that's the problem. Can we set aside the idea that profit generation = healthy economy? Because the fact is that profit does not drive a healthy economy. It may have done so during previous generations, but the interconnected nature of our global society is making it impossible to use profit as the prime motivator for doing work. As we become more globally interdependent, the closed nature of our social system becomes clear. A closed system only functions if it is in balance. And you cannot draw excess from a closed system without damaging or severely unbalancing that system.

We need to focus on actually solving real problems for the benefit of everyone. If we only evaluate needs based on our ability to profit from them, then our problems will never actually get solved. They will only be serviced by people who can provide temporary relief in exchange for profit. In the mean time the problems we service will get bigger and harder to deal with until pain forces us to work for solutions instead of money, or some other kind of personal gain.

'Love your neighbor as yourself', is much more than just a pretty saying. We will only be free of our suffering when we finally come together as friends, in love, and mutual guarantee. http://www.perceivingreality.com

Peace to all of you and to all of yours.
